tourBios.exmtStatus: Exempt - Top-75 Money Winner from 2014 Web.com Tour Regular Season
tourBios.curYearHigh: Finished the Web.com Tour season with 23 starts, one win, five top-25s and 14 cuts made. Was 45th in the final priority-ranking order...Collected his first career win with a five-stroke victory at the wind-plagued Cartagena de Indias at Karibana Championship in early March. Shot a final-round, 3-under 69 to finish 11 under and take home the $126,000 first-place check. Emerged from a packed leaderboard on the weekend and played the final 44 holes with only one bogey. A third-round 67, played over a two-day span, gave him a share of the 54-hole lead at 8 under. Had the luxury of being an hour in front of the final groups because officials did not repair for the final round, which actually started before the third round was completed. Early birdies at Nos. 2 and 3 gave him the outright lead, which he would maintain the rest of the way. Rolled in a 15-foot birdie putt on the final hole and waited out the remaining 15 players. All stumbled with bogeys on the final nine and dropped further off the pace. Winning check vaulted him to No. 2 on the money list behind fellow rookie winner Patrick Rodgers after three events...Posted consecutive top 25s in Chile (T16), Louisiana (T23) and Mexico (T23)...On March 30 (after Louisiana), Monday-qualified into his first PGA TOUR event, the Shell Houston Open, in his home state of Texas. Shot rounds of 76-73 to miss the cut...Only top 25 in his final nine Regular Season events came at the Nova Scotia Open (T16) in early July. Was the first-round leader in Halifax after firing a 64...Finished 21st on the Regular Season money list to secure his PGA TOUR card for 2015-16...In the Web.com Tour Finals, made the cut in the first three tournaments, but his best outing of the three was only a T47 at the opening Hotel Fitness Championship in Fort Wayne...Finished No. 108 in the Web.com Tour Finals.
tourBios.carHigh:
Has won twice on the Adams Golf Tour.

2014: With rounds of 71-67-67-69-67-68 (20-under), claimed runner-up honors at the Web.com Tour Qualifying Tournament at PGA National in December.

2009-2010-2011: Played in one Web.com Tour each year (Fort Smith, Midland and Lafayette, respectively), missing the cut in all three.
tourBios.otherCarHigh: Named a Ping All-American three times at Arkansas and was All-Southeastern Conference three times. Won two events in college. Fought from four down with five holes to play to square the final match of the 2009 NCAA Championship at Inverness Club, only to have Bronson Burgoon nearly hole his approach shot on No. 18 to snare the title for Texas A&M. In high school, played on the district championship team three times and finished third as an individual in the Texas State Championship.
tourBios.personal: Attended Port Neches-Groves High in Port Neches, Texas...If he weren't a professional golfer, says he would be a fishing guide...Favorite food is crawfish and raw oysters...Favorite TV show is "Seinfeld." ...Other favorites include the Los Angeles Dodgers, Atlanta Braves, "Duck Dynasty," Justin Timberlake and Clayton Kershaw...Most famous person he's met is President George W. Bush while fishing in Dallas...Admits to a guilty pleasure of enjoying the TV show "Pretty Little Liars."...Once shot 58 at his home course, nine-hole "Pea Patch" in Groves, Texas (since closed down), which played about 6,300 yards. "58 is 58."

tourBios.exmtStatus: 45th on the 2015 Web.com Tour priority list

tourBios.carHigh:
Has won twice on the Adams Golf Tour.

2014: With rounds of 71-67-67-69-67-68 (20-under), claimed runner-up honors at the Web.com Tour Qualifying Tournament at PGA National in December.

2011: Made one Web.com Tour start, at the Chitimacha Louisiana Open (missed the cut). 

2010: Again made one Web.com Tour start, this time at the WNB Golf Classic, where he missed the cut. 

2009: Played in the Fort Smith Classic, missing the cut. 

2010-2011: Played in one Web.com Tour each year (Fort Smith, Midland and Lafayette, respectively), missing the cut in all three.
Amateur: Named a Ping All-American three times at Arkansas and was All-Southeastern Conference three times. Won two events in college. Fought from four down with five holes to play to square the final match of the 2009 NCAA Championship at Inverness Club, only to have Bronson Burgoon nearly hole his approach shot on No. 18 to snare the title for Texas A&M. In high school, played on the district championship team three times and finished third as an individual in the Texas State Championship.
tourBios.personal: Attended Port Neches-Groves High in Port Neches, Texas...If he weren't a professional golfer, says he would be a fishing guide...Favorite food is crawfish and raw oysters...Favorite TV show is "Seinfeld." ...Other favorites include the Los Angeles Dodgers, Atlanta Braves, "Duck Dynasty," Justin Timberlake and Clayton Kershaw...Most famous person he's met is President George W. Bush while fishing in Dallas...Admits to a guilty pleasure of enjoying the TV show "Pretty Little Liars."...Once shot 58 at his home course, nine-hole "Pea Patch" in Groves, Texas (since closed down), which played about 6,300 yards. "Fifty-eight is 58," he says.

dyn.dynResults: His best finish on the PGA TOUR was T51st in 2016 at the Valero Texas Open.
dyn.dynStats: He ranks T5th in Approach 75-100 yards (RTP Sco on the PGA TOUR.
